twenty-eight
composed by five hundred great arhats and others
tripiá¹­aka master Xuanzang respectfully received
How many are visible?
How many are invisible?
Question: Why not ask how many have form and how many are formless?
Answer: Because the author of the treatise intended it to be so.
One composes the treatise according to their intention.
As long as it does not contradict the nature of dharmas, one should not criticize it. Some say:
Because there is no formless realm among the created [dharmas],
One cannot ask how many have form.
The question also does not have unconditioned [dharmas],
So one should not ask later how many are conditioned and how many are unconditioned.
Answer: One should not ask.
But the later question should be known as a remainder of the previous statement.
Some say:ğŸ”½In order to adorn the meaning with various texts and various explanations,
Making it easier to understand.
Furthermore, in order to illuminate each other through two gates, two steps, two summaries, two lights, two torches, two shadows, and two rays,
just as unconditioned [dharmas] are not asked about because they are formless,
in the same way, unconditioned [dharmas] are not asked about because they are unconditioned.
Just as unconditioned [dharmas] are unconditioned and can be asked about,
in the same way, although unconditioned [dharmas] are formless, they should also be asked about.
In this way, the two gates illuminate each other,
causing one to know that the principle of the questions and answers before and after isé€š.
Other masters say:
Here, the conditioned form is distinguished as to how many are visible, etc.
Having already raised the conditioned form as the chapter,
how can it be asked again how many have form, etc.?
Because the word form already reveals that it has form.
This is because the substance of form all has the meaning of change and obstruction.
Because it has the meaning of form, it is called having form.
It is not like having clothes and having children, etc.
In how many places are the great elements and the conditioned [form] visible?
The answer is: one, namely the form realm.
Question: Why is the form realm called visible?
Answer: The eye faculty is called seeing because it has the function of seeing.
The form realm that is seen has the seeing eye, so it is called visible.
Like having a master, etc., or the seer.
This shows that the form realm is coarse.
It can be shown that it exists here and there, with differences in appearance.
The shown form has that which can show it, so it is called visible.
Like having a name, etc.
Or the seer is the various images.
Only the form realm can have images, so it is called visible.
The others are not like this.
How many are invisible?
Answer: Eight and two parts.
The eight are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, sound, smell, and taste realms.
The two parts are
the touch realm and the dharma realm.
Although all the touch realms are included in the invisible,
not all of them are derivative form.
If the derivative form is also invisible,ğŸ”½...
This is because the remaining ones are not what is being asked about, so only a part is mentioned.
The same applies to the dharma realm.
How many of the realms are resistant?
The answer is: nine and one part.
The nine are the five inner sense bases and the four outer sense bases.
One part refers to the sense base of touch.
Although all the sense bases of touch are included in the resistant,
not all of them are derivative form.
If derivative form is also resistant,
this is what is being asked about, the remaining are not what is being asked about, so only a part is mentioned.
How many are non-resistant?
The answer is: one part, namely the dharma realm.
Although all the dharma realms are included in the non-resistant,
not all of them are derivative form.
If derivative form is also non-resistant,
this is what is being asked about, the remaining are not what is being asked about, so only a part is mentioned.
However, there are three kinds of resistance: 1. Obstructive resistance,
which refers to the ten sense bases of form.
2. Objective-support resistance, which refers to the five sense faculties of form and the mind and mental factors.
Third, the object-based resistance.
It refers to the mind and mental factors.
Here, it refers to the obstruction-based resistance, not the others.
How many of the elements are the great elements and how many are the derivative form?
Answer: Nine and two parts.
The nine are as previously explained.
The two parts refer to
the element of touch and the element of dharmas.
Although all the elements of touch are included in the contaminated,
not all of them are derivative form.
If the derivative form is also contaminated,
it is what is being asked about here. The rest are not being asked about, so it is said to be a part.
Not all of the element of dharmas
are included in the uncontaminated.
Also, not all of them are derivative form.
If the derivative form is also uncontaminated,
it is what is being asked about here. The rest are not being asked about, so it is said to be a part.
How many are uncontaminated?
Answer: One part, namely the element of dharmas.
Not all of the element of dharmas are included in the uncontaminated.
Also, not all of them are derivative form.
If the derivative form is also uncontaminated,
This is because what is asked about is partial.
How many of the elements that are great elements and derivative form are conditioned?
The answer is: nine and two in part.
The nine are as explained above.
The two in part refer to
the element of tangibility and the element of mental objects.
Although all the elements of tangibility are included in the conditioned,
not all of them are derivative form.
If derivative form is also conditioned,
this is because what is asked about is partial.ğŸ”½Not all the elements of mental objects are included in the conditioned,
and not all of them are derivative form.
If derivative form is also conditioned,
this is because what is asked about is partial.
How many are unconditioned?
The answer is: none.
This is because they are all conditioned.
How many of the elements that are great elements and derivative form are past?
The answer is: eleven in part.
This means excluding the mental faculty.ğŸ”½Although all the elements of the eye are included in the derivative,
not all of them are in the past.
Because some exist in the future and present worlds.
If it is derivative form and also past,
it is what is being asked about here. The rest are not being asked about, so it is said to be a part.
The ear, nose, tongue, body, form, sound, and smell bases are also like this.
Not all tangible object bases are included in derivative form.
Nor do all exist in the past.
If it is derivative form and also past,
it is what is being asked about here. The rest are not being asked about, so it is said to be a part.
The dharma base is also like this.
As explained for the past,
the future and present are also explained in the same way.
Because there are many, etc.
How many bases are derivative form and good?
The answer is: three parts.
Although all form bases are included in derivative form,
not all are of the nature of good.
If it is derivative form and also of the nature of good,
it is what is being asked about here. The rest are not being asked about, so it is said to be a part.
The sound base is also like this.
Not all dharma bases are included in derivative form.
It is also not the case that all of them are of good nature.
If they are derivative form and also of good nature,
they are the subject of this question, while the rest are not the subject of the question, and therefore it is said that they are a part of it.
How many are unwholesome?
The answer is: three parts, as explained above.
How many are indeterminate?
The answer is: seven, three parts.
The seven are the five inner sense bases and the sense bases of smell and taste.
The three parts are
the sense bases of form, sound, and touch.
Although all sense bases of form are included in derivative form,
it is not the case that all of them are indeterminate.
If they are derivative form and also indeterminate,
they are the subject of this question, while the rest are not the subject of the question, and therefore it is said that they are a part of it.
The same is true for the sense base of sound.
Although all sense bases of touch are included in the indeterminate,
it is not the case that all of them are derivative form.
If they are indeterminate and also derivative form,
they are the subject of this question, while the rest are not the subject of the question, and therefore it is said that they are a part of it.
How many sense bases are derivative form and are bound to the desire realm?
The answer is: two, and nine parts.
The second is the two sense bases of smell and taste.
The nine that are partially homogeneous are
the five inner sense bases,
and the sense bases of form, sound, touch, and mental objects.
Although all eye sense bases are included in the derivative [form],
not all are bound to the desire realm.
If they are derivative [form] and also bound to the desire realm,
they are what is being asked about here. The rest are not being asked about, so it is said to be partially [homogeneous].
The same is true for the sense bases of ear, nose, tongue, body, form, and sound.
Not all touch sense bases are included in the derivative [form],
and not all are bound to the desire realm.
If they are derivative [form] and also bound to the desire realm,
they are what is being asked about here. The rest are not being asked about, so it is said to be partially [homogeneous].
The same is true for the sense base of mental objects.
How many are bound to the form realm?
The answer is: nine that are partially homogeneous, as explained above.
How many are bound to the formless realm?
The answer is: none.
Because they have no form.
How many sense bases are derivative [form] and are also the great elements?
The answer is: one that is partially [derivative form].
Namely, the sense base of mental objects.
Not all mental objects are included in the derivative [form].
It is also not the case that all of them are derivative.
If they are derivative and also included in the category of training,
they are the subject of this question. The rest are not the subject of the question, so it is said that they are a part of it.
How many are post-learner?
The answer is one part, as explained above.
How many are neither learner nor post-learner?
The answer is nine and two parts.
The nine are the five internal sense bases,
and the four external sense bases.
The two parts are
the sense base of touch and the sense base of mental objects.
Although all the sense bases of touch are not included in the category of learner or post-learner,
it is not the case that all of them are derivative.
If they are neither learner nor post-learner and also derivative,
they are the subject of this question. The rest are not the subject of the question, so it is said that they are a part of it.
Not all the sense bases of mental objects are not included in the category of learner or post-learner.
It is also not the case that all of them are derivative.
If they are neither learner nor post-learner,
and also derivative,
they are the subject of this question. The rest are not the subject of the question, so it is said that they are a part of it.
How many of the great elements and derivatives are eliminated by seeing?
The answer is none.
Because there are definitely no forms that are eliminated by seeing.
How many are eliminated by cultivation?
The answer is nine and two parts.
The nine are as explained above.
The two parts refer to the sense base of touch and the sense base of mental objects.
Although all the sense base of touch is included in what is eliminated by cultivation,
it is not all derivative.
If it is eliminated by cultivation and also derivative,
it is what is asked about here. The rest are not asked about, so it is said to be a part.
Not all the sense base of mental objects is included in what is eliminated by cultivation,
and not all of it is derivative.
If it is eliminated by cultivation and also derivative,
it is what is asked about here. The rest are not asked about, so it is said to be a part.
How many are not eliminated?
The answer is one part.
It refers to the sense base of mental objects.ğŸ”½Not all the sense base of mental objects is included in what is not eliminated,
and not all of it is derivative.
If it is derivative and also not eliminated,
This is the partial answer to the question.
If one possesses the primary elements, does one also possess the derivative form?
The answer is: Those who possess the primary elements
also possess derivative form.
There are those who possess derivative form but not the primary elements.
This refers to noble ones born in the formless realm.
Who possesses the primary elements and derivative form?
This refers to all sentient beings in the desire and form realms.
This is the general explanation.
If we explain it specifically,
there are some sentient beings
who possess many primary elements and much derivative form.
There are some sentient beings
who possess few primary elements and little derivative form.
Those who possess many primary elements and much derivative form
are like the sentient beings in the great ocean who have attained such physical forms.

Their size is one hundred, two hundred, three hundred, four hundred, five hundred, six hundred, or seven hundred yojanas.ğŸ”½Like the physical form attained by the asura king RÄhu, which is vast in size.
Like the physical form attained by those in the ultimate heaven.
The size is 16,000 yojanas.
Those who possess a small amount of primary elements and a small amount of derivative form,
are like mosquitoes, gnats, and other small insects in the water.
They are extremely subtle, not within the range of the human eye.
Question: Why do the noble ones who are born in the formless realm
only possess derivative form and not primary elements?
Answer: In that realm there is no form.
Moreover, they do not possess the primary elements of other realms.
Because contaminated dharmas are abandoned by transcending the stages.
Derivative form is not like this, because it is common to the uncontaminated. Therefore, one possesses [derivative form] of different stages.
There are no noble ones who do not possess the uncontaminated precepts.
Therefore, the noble ones who are born in that realm only possess derivative form.ğŸ”½Among them, those in training possess the derivative form that accompanies training.
Those beyond training possess the derivative form that accompanies beyond training.
If one does not possess the primary elements,
does one also not possess the derivative form?
Answer: Those who do not possess derivative form
do not possess the primary elements.
There are those who do not possess the primary elements but not the derivative form.
It refers to the noble ones born in the formless realm.
Who does not accomplish derivative form and the primary elements?
It refers to all ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
Because there is no form at all in that realm.
Moreover, because one does not accomplish the form of the lower realms, the contaminated forms are lost when one is born above.
Because the uncontaminated forms have not yet been attained by them.
In the affirmative question, what is not included?
And yet it is still necessary to establish the negative question.
The answer is: The affirmative question only includes all sentient beings in the desire and form realms.ğŸ”½And it includes all noble ones in the formless realm.
It does not yet include all ordinary beings in the formless realm.
In order to include them, the negative question is established again.
If one accomplishes the primary elements, does one also accomplish wholesome form?
The answer is: Four alternatives should be established.
There is accomplishment of the primary elements but not wholesome form.
It refers to those in the egg-shell state.
If ordinary beings dwell in the womb,
or if born in the desire realm and abiding in non-restraint,
and neither-restraint-nor-non-restraint.
There is no good bodily or verbal expression.
Even if there is, it is lost.
In that place, in the egg,
the sentient beings in the womb and those born before have all the expression and non-expression of form.
Because of the loss of the basis and the commonality of the group, all are abandoned.
At this stage, one is not yet able to give rise to expression.
And there is no principle of entering concentration,
therefore one does not accomplish all good form.
Question: Why is one not yet able to give rise to expression at this stage?
Answer: Because the supported body is extremely weak.
Only when the body is strong can one give rise to bodily action.
Moreover, the mind at this stage is extremely weak.
Only the superior mind can give rise to bodily action.
Moreover, the mind at this stage turns inward.
The mind that turns outward can give rise to bodily action.
Moreover, in this stage, the fetus is cramped and cannot move,
let alone give rise to bodily action.
However, there are times when the fetus moves.
This is due to the power of the wind, not the mind.
Indicative form must be produced by the power of the mind.
Question: What is the reason that there is no principle of entering concentration in this state?
Answer: Because in this state, the body and mind are both weak and inferior.
Also, because there are no conditions for the practice of entering concentration.
One who has attained patience abandons patience at the end of life.
As previously extensively analyzed in the chapter on karma.
The extensive explanation of the four kinds of birth is also like the chapter on karma.
If one is born in the desire realm and abides in neither discipline nor undiscipline, and has no good bodily or verbal indicative form,
That is, in sleep, intoxication, and stupor.
And abandoning the practice, not seeking to produce indicative form.
Even if one has it, it is lost.
That is, it is lost for three reasons.
First, the intention ceases.
Second, abandoning the practice.
Third, the limit of force is exceeded.
This is also extensively explained like the chapter on karma.
There are those who accomplish good form but not the great elements.
That is, noble ones born in the formless realm.
Because they are noble ones, they accomplish good form. Because they are born in the formless realm,
They do not accomplish the great elements.
Those noble ones are both learners and non-learners.
Learners accomplish learner wholesome form.
Non-learners accomplish non-learner wholesome form.
There are those who accomplish the great elements and also wholesome form.
This refers to noble ones dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm and abiding in precepts,
if abiding in non-precepts,
and in neither precepts nor non-precepts,
currently possessing wholesome bodily and verbal expression,
or previously having it without losing it.
If born in the form realm and abiding in the womb as a noble one,
one definitely accomplishes contaminated and uncontaminated non-expression, because the power of the path is strong.
If born in the desire realm and abiding in precepts,
this refers to abiding in the three precepts as appropriate,
abiding in non-precepts and in neither precepts nor non-precepts,
currently possessing wholesome bodily and verbal expression.
This refers to not sleeping,ğŸ”½not being drunk,
not being dazed,
not abandoning effort,
seeking to give rise to expressed karma,
or previously having it without losing it.
This refers to the three conditions as explained above.
If one is born in the form realm, one definitely possesses the precepts of the meditative absorptions.
There is wholesome form that is not possessed, and there is form that is not wholesome.
This refers to ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
Because they are born in the formless realm, they do not possess the great elements.
Because wholesome contaminated form is abandoned by transcending the realm.
Because they have not yet attained wholesome uncontaminated form. If one possesses the great elements, does one also possess unwholesome form?
The answer is: Those who possess unwholesome formğŸ”½definitely possess the great elements.
There are those who possess the great elements
but not unwholesome form.
This refers to those in the egg and womb stages,
and those born in the desire realm who abide in precepts,
as well as those who are neither in precepts nor not in precepts,
who do not have unwholesome bodily and verbal expression,
even if they had it, it has been lost.
If born in the form realm,
If one possesses unwholesome form, one definitely abides in the desire realm.
There is no one in the desire realm who does not possess the great elements, because they necessarily have a body.
For this reason, it can be used as a subsequent phrase.
The answer and explanation of the remaining phrases should be understood according to the above.
If one possesses the great elements, does one possess the obscured-neutral form?
The answer is: Those who possess obscured-neutral form definitely possess the great elements.
There are those who possess the great elements but not obscured-neutral form.
Namely, those born in the desire realm or those born in the form realm.
Currently lacking obscured-neutral bodily and verbal expression.
Namely, if one possesses obscured-neutral form, one definitely abides in the form realm.
There is no one in the form realm who does not possess the great elements, because they necessarily have a body.
Therefore, this can be used as the subsequent phrase.
The answer is: There is no one born in the desire realm who gives rise to obscured-neutral expression.
Because wholesome and defiled expression and action depend on one's own body or others' bodies.
If one possesses the great elements, does one possess the unobscured-neutral form?
The answer is: It is so.
If one possesses the unobscured-neutral form,
does one possess the great elements?
The answer is: It is so.
Because one who possesses the great elements necessarily possesses the bodily faculties, etc.
If one possesses the body faculty, etc., one must possess the primary elements.
All sentient beings born in the desire realm and form realm
all possess the primary elements and unobstructed indeterminate form.
Those born in the formless realm do not possess either.
If one possesses the primary elements, does one also possess wholesome and unwholesome form?
The answer is: There are those who possess the primary elements but not wholesome or unwholesome form.
This refers to those in the egg womb.
If ordinary beings dwell in the womb,
if born in the desire realm and abiding in neither discipline nor undiscipline,
without wholesome or unwholesome bodily and verbal expression,
even if they had it, it would be lost.
There are those who possess the primary elements and also wholesome form but not unwholesome form.
This refers to noble ones dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm and abiding in discipline,
without unwholesome bodily and verbal expression,
even if they had it, it would be lost.
If abiding in neither discipline nor undiscipline,
currently possessing wholesome bodily and verbal expression,
or having it previously without loss.
There is no unwholesome bodily or verbal expression.
Even if there is, it is lost.
If one is born in the form realm and possesses the four great elements,
one also has unwholesome form but not wholesome form.
This refers to being born in the desire realm and abiding in non-restraint.
There is no wholesome bodily or verbal expression.
Even if there is, it is lost.
If one abides in neither restraint nor non-restraint,
one presently has unwholesome bodily and verbal expression.
Or one previously had it and did not lose it.
There is no wholesome bodily or verbal expression.
Even if there is, it is lost.
There are those who possess the four great elements and also wholesome and unwholesome form.
This refers to being born in the desire realm and abiding in restraint.
One presently has unwholesome bodily and verbal expression, or one previously had it and did not lose it.
If one abides in non-restraint,
one presently has wholesome bodily and verbal expression.
Or one previously had it and did not lose it.
If one abides in neither restraint nor non-restraint,
one presently has wholesome and unwholesome bodily and verbal expression.
Or one previously had it and did not lose it.
If one possesses wholesome and unwholesome form, does one also possess the four great elements?
Answer: Yes.
It means that one who possesses good or bad form must be in the desire realm.
One who is in the desire realm definitely possesses the great elements.
If one possesses the great elements, does one also possess good and obscured-neutral form?
The answer is: There are those who possess the great elements but not good or obscured-neutral form.
It refers to those in the egg-shell state.
Or ordinary beings dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm, dwelling in neither discipline nor undiscipline.
Without good bodily and verbal manifest karma.
Even if one had it, it would be lost.
There are those who possess the great elements and also good form but not obscured-neutral form.
It refers to noble ones dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm, dwelling in discipline.
If dwelling in undiscipline or neither discipline nor undiscipline.
Currently possessing good bodily and verbal manifest karma.
Or having it previously without loss.
If born in the form realm, currently without obscured-neutral bodily and verbal manifest karma.
There are those who possess the great elements and also good and obscured-neutral form.
That is to say, if one is born in the form realm and currently possesses manifest wholesome or unwholesome bodily or verbal expression.
If one possesses wholesome or unwholesome and indeterminate form, does one also possess the primary elements?
The answer is: It is so.
That is to say, one who possesses wholesome or unwholesome and indeterminate form must be in the form realm.
One who is in the form realm definitely possesses the primary elements.
If one possesses the primary elements, does one also possess wholesome or unwholesome and indeterminate form?
The answer is: There are those who possess the primary elements and also unwholesome and indeterminate form but not wholesome form.
That is to say, those who are in the egg-born class.
Or ordinary beings dwelling in the womb.
Or those born in the desire realm who abide in neither discipline nor undiscipline.
And those who are neither disciplined nor undisciplined.
Who do not have manifest wholesome or unwholesome bodily or verbal expression.
Even if they had it, they have lost it.
There are those who possess the primary elements and also wholesome and unwholesome and indeterminate form.
That is to say, noble ones dwelling in the womb.
Or those born in the desire realm who abide in discipline.
Or those who abide in undiscipline.
And those who are neither disciplined nor undisciplined.
One who currently possesses good bodily and verbal expressions,
or who previously possessed them without losing them.
If one is born in the form realm,
If one possesses good and unobscured indeterminate form,
do they also possess the primary elements?
The answer is: It is so.
That is to say, one who possesses good and unobscured indeterminate form,
must be in the desire or form realms.
One who is in the desire or form realms,
definitely possesses the primary elements.
If one possesses the primary elements, do they also possess unwholesome and obscured indeterminate form?
The answer is: No.
That is to say, one who possesses unwholesome form must be in the desire realm.
One who possesses obscured indeterminate form must be in the form realm.
Because no sentient being is born in both realms simultaneously.
If one possesses the primary elements, do they also possess unwholesome and unobscured indeterminate form?
The answer is: There are those who possess the primary elements,
and also unobscured indeterminate form,
but not unwholesome form.ğŸ”½That is to say, those in the egg or membrane,
and those dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm and abiding in the precepts,
and neither-restraint-nor-non-restraint.
There is no unwholesome bodily or verbal expression.
Even if there is, it is lost.
If one is born in the form realm and possesses the primary elements,
one also possesses unwholesome and unobscured-neutral form.
That is to say, if one is born in the desire realm and abides in non-restraint,
if one abides in restraint,
and in neither-restraint-nor-non-restraint,
and presently possesses unwholesome bodily and verbal expression,
or if one previously possessed it and has not lost it, does one also possess the primary elements of unwholesome and unobscured-neutral form?
The answer is: It is so.
That is to say, one who possesses unwholesome and unobscured-neutral form
must be in the desire realm.
One who is in the desire realm definitely possesses the primary elements.
If one possesses the primary elements, does one also possess obscured-neutral and unobscured-neutral form?
The answer is: There are those who possess the primary elements
and also unobscured-neutral form,
but do not possess obscured-neutral form.
That is to say, if one is born in the desire realm,
if one is born in the form realm,
There is no present manifestation of non-obscuring-indeterminate bodily and verbal actions.
There are those who possess the primary elements,
and also those who possess obscured-indeterminate and non-obscuring-indeterminate form.
This refers to those born in the form realm who currently possess obscured-indeterminate bodily and verbal actions.
If one possesses obscured-indeterminate and non-obscuring-indeterminate form, do they also possess the primary elements?
The answer is yes.
This is because those who possess these two kinds of indeterminate form
are necessarily in the form realm.
Those in the form realm definitely possess the primary elements. If one possesses the primary elements, do they also possess wholesome, unwholesome, and obscured-indeterminate form?
The answer is no.
This is because those who possess wholesome and unwholesome form are necessarily in the desire realm.
Those who possess wholesome and obscured-indeterminate form
are necessarily in the form realm.
Because no sentient being is born in two realms simultaneously.
If one possesses the primary elements,
do they also possess wholesome, unwholesome, and non-obscuring-indeterminate form?
The answer is: There are those who possess the primary elementsğŸ”½and also non-obscuring-indeterminate form,
but not wholesome or unwholesome form.
It refers to those who are in the egg.
If ordinary beings are in the womb.
If born in the desire realm, abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline,
without good or bad bodily and verbal expressions,
even if they exist, they are lost.
There are those who possess the great elements and also good and unobstructed indeterminate form,
but not bad form.
It refers to the noble ones who are in the womb.
If born in the desire realm, abiding in discipline,
without bad bodily and verbal expressions,
even if they exist, they are lost.
If abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline,
currently possessing good bodily and verbal expressions,
or previously existing without loss,
without bad bodily and verbal expressions,
even if they exist, they are lost.
If born in the form realm, there are those who possess the great elements,
and also bad and unobstructed indeterminate form, but not good form.
It refers to those born in the desire realm who abide in non-discipline,
without good bodily and verbal expressions,
even if they exist, they are lost.
If abiding in neither discipline nor non-discipline,
If one currently has unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or if one previously had them and has not lost them,
and does not have wholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
even if one had them, one has lost them.
There are those who possess the great elements and also wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate form.
Namely, those born in the desire realm who abide in the precepts,
currently have unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or if they previously had them and have not lost them.
If one abides in the non-precepts,
currently has wholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or if one previously had them and has not lost them.
If one abides in neither the precepts nor the non-precepts,
currently has wholesome and unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or if one previously had them and has not lost them.
If one possesses wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate form,
do they also possess the great elements?
The answer is: It is so.
Namely, those who possess these three kinds of form,
must be in the desire realm.
Those in the desire realm definitely possess the great elements.
If one possesses the great elements, do they also possess wholesome, obscured indeterminate, and unobscured indeterminate form?
Answer: There are those who possess the great elements and also unobscured-neutral form,
but not wholesome or obscured-neutral form.
Namely, those in the egg-shell state.
If ordinary beings are dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm, dwelling in neither discipline nor undiscipline.
And neither disciplined nor undisciplined.
Without wholesome bodily and verbal expression.
Even if they have it, they have lost it.
There are those who possess the great elements and also wholesome and unobscured-neutral form,
but not obscured-neutral form.
Namely, noble ones dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm, dwelling in discipline.
If dwelling in undiscipline or neither disciplined nor undisciplined.
Currently possessing wholesome bodily and verbal expression.
Or having it previously without losing it.
If born in the form realm, currently without obscured-neutral bodily and verbal expression.
There are those who possess the great elements and also wholesome, obscured-neutral, and unobscured-neutral form.
Namely, those born in the form realm who currently possess obscured-neutral bodily and verbal expression.
If one possesses wholesome, obscured neutral, and unobscured neutral form,
do they possess the primary elements?
The answer is: it is so.
This means that one who possesses these three types of form
must be in the form realm.
One who is in the form realm definitely possesses the primary elements.
If one possesses the primary elements,
do they possess unwholesome, obscured neutral, and unobscured neutral form?
The answer is: no.
This means that one who possesses unwholesome and unobscured neutral form
must be in the desire realm.
One who possesses obscured neutral and unobscured neutral form
must be in the form realm.
Because no single sentient being can be born in two realms simultaneously.
If one possesses the primary elements,
do they possess wholesome, unwholesome, obscured neutral, and unobscured neutral form?
The answer is: no.
This means that one who possesses wholesome, unwholesome, and unobscured neutral form
must be in the desire realm.
One who possesses wholesome, obscured neutral, and unobscured neutral form
must be in the form realm.
Because no sentient beings are born simultaneously in two realms. If one possesses wholesome form, does one also possess unwholesome form?
The answer is that one should make a fourfold distinction.
There are those who possess wholesome form but not unwholesome form.
This refers to noble ones dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm and abiding in moral discipline,
without unwholesome bodily or verbal expression, even if they existed but were lost.
If abiding in neither moral discipline nor immoral discipline,
currently possessing wholesome bodily and verbal expression,
or previously possessing it without loss.
Without unwholesome bodily or verbal expression,
even if they existed but were lost.
If born in the form realm, or if noble ones
are born in the formless realm.
There are those who possess unwholesome form but not wholesome form.
This refers to those born in the desire realm, abiding in immoral discipline,
without wholesome bodily or verbal expression,
even if they existed but were lost.
If abiding in neither moral discipline nor immoral discipline,
currently possessing unwholesome bodily and verbal expression,
or previously possessing it without loss.
Without wholesome bodily or verbal expression,
even if they existed but were lost.
There are those who possess both wholesome and unwholesome form.
Namely, those born in the desire realm who abide in the precepts,
and who currently possess unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or who previously possessed them and have not lost them.
If they abide in the non-precepts,
and currently possess wholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or who previously possessed them and have not lost them.
If they abide in neither the precepts nor the non-precepts,
and currently possess wholesome and unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or who previously possessed them and have not lost them.
There are those who do not possess wholesome form,
and also unwholesome form.
Namely, those in the egg membrane,
or ordinary beings dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm and abiding in neither the precepts nor the non-precepts,
without wholesome or unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
even if they had them, they have been lost.
If ordinary beings are born in the formless realm.
If one possesses wholesome form,
do they possess obscured indeterminate form?
The answer is: Those who possess obscured indeterminate form,ğŸ”½they definitely possess wholesome form.
Or they may possess wholesome form.
It is not the case for the form of the obscured and neutral category.
This refers to the noble ones dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm, abiding in the precepts,
if abiding in neither precepts nor not precepts,
currently possessing good bodily and verbal expressions,
or having them previously without losing them.
If born in the form realm, currently lacking the bodily and verbal expressions of the obscured and neutral category.
If the noble ones are born in the formless realm.
If one possesses good form, does one also possess the form of the unobscured and neutral category?
The answer is that one should make a fourfold distinction.
There are those who possess good form
but not the form of the unobscured and neutral category.
This refers to the noble ones born in the formless realm.
There are those who possess the form of the unobscured and neutral category but not good form.
This refers to those dwelling in an egg.
If ordinary beings dwell in the womb,
if born in the desire realm, abiding in neither precepts nor not precepts,
lacking good bodily and verbal expressions,
even if having them, having lost them.
There are those who possess good formğŸ”½and
There is also no obscured neutral form.
This refers to noble ones dwelling in the womb.
If born in the desire realm, abiding in precepts,
if abiding in neither precepts nor not precepts,
currently possessing good bodily and verbal expressions,
or previously possessing them without losing them.
If born in the form realm, there is no possession of good form,
and no obscured neutral form.
This refers to ordinary beings born in the formless realm.
If one possesses good form,
do they possess unwholesome and obscured neutral form?
The answer is no.
Those who possess unwholesome form
must be in the desire realm.
Those who possess obscured neutral form
must be in the form realm.
Because no single sentient being is born in two realms simultaneously. If one possesses good form,
do they possess unwholesome and unobscured neutral form?
The answer is: There are those who possess good form
but not unwholesome or unobscured neutral form.
This refers to noble ones born in the formless realm.
There are those who possess wholesome form and also unobscured-indeterminate form,
but not unwholesome form.
This refers to noble ones dwelling in the womb,
or those born in the desire realm who abide in precepts,
without unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
even if they had them before, they have been lost.
If they abide in neither precepts nor non-precepts,
and currently possess wholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or previously possessed them and have not lost them,
but do not have unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
even if they had them before, they have been lost.
If they are born in the form realm,
there are those who possess wholesome form and also unwholesome and unobscured-indeterminate form.
This refers to those born in the desire realm who abide in precepts,
and currently possess unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or previously possessed them and have not lost them.
If they abide in non-precepts,
and currently possess wholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or previously possessed them and have not lost them.
If they abide in neither precepts nor non-precepts,
and currently possess wholesome and unwholesome bodily and verbal expressions,
or previously possessed them and have not lost them.
If one possesses non-virtuous and unobscured-neutral form, does one also possess virtuous form?
The answer is: Some do,
some do not.
How is it that some do?
It is as explained above.
How is it that some do not?
It refers to those born in the desire realm who abide in non-discipline,
without virtuous bodily and verbal expressions,
even if they had them, they have been lost.
If they abide in neither discipline nor non-discipline,
and currently possess non-virtuous bodily and verbal expressions,
or if they previously had them and have not lost them,
but do not have virtuous bodily and verbal expressions,
even if they had them, they have been lost.
If one possesses virtuous form, does one also possess obscured-neutral and unobscured-neutral form?
The answer is: There are those who possess virtuous form,
but not obscured-neutral or unobscured-neutral form.
It refers to noble ones born in the formless realm.
There are those who possess virtuous form and also unobscured-neutral form,
but not obscured-neutral form.ğŸ”½It refers to noble ones abiding in the womb,
or those born in the desire realm who abide in discipline,
If one abides in neither moral discipline nor immoral discipline,
and currently possesses good bodily and verbal expressions,
or previously had them without losing them,
if one is born in the form realm and currently has no obscured indeterminate bodily and verbal expressions,
one may possess good form, as well as obscured indeterminate and unobscured indeterminate form.
This refers to those born in the form realm who currently have obscured indeterminate bodily and verbal expressions.
Even if one possesses obscured indeterminate and unobscured indeterminate form,
does one possess good form?
The answer is: so.
This refers to those who possess obscured indeterminate and unobscured indeterminate form.
They must be in the form realm.
Those in the form realm definitely possess good form.
If one possesses good form,
does one possess unwholesome, obscured indeterminate, and unobscured indeterminate form?
The answer is: no.
This refers to those who possess unwholesome and unobscured indeterminate form.
They must be in the desire realm.
Those who possess obscured indeterminate and unobscured indeterminate form
must be in the form realm.
Because no sentient being is born in both realms simultaneously. If one possesses unwholesome form,
do they possess obscured indeterminate form?
The answer is no.
Those who possess unwholesome form
are necessarily in the desire realm.
Those who possess obscured indeterminate form
are necessarily in the form realm.
Because no sentient being is born in both realms simultaneously. If one possesses unwholesome form,
do they possess unobscured indeterminate form?
The answer is: Those who possess unwholesome formğŸ”½definitely possess unobscured indeterminate form.
There are those who possess unobscured indeterminate form
but not unwholesome form.
This refers to those in the egg and womb,
and those born in the desire realm who abide in neither discipline nor undiscipline.
Those without unwholesome bodily and verbal expression,
even if they had it, have lost it.
If born in the form realm, those who possess unwholesome form,
do they possess obscured indeterminate and unobscured indeterminate form?
The answer is no.
As explained above.
If one possesses obscured and neutral form,
do they possess unobscured and neutral form?
The answer is: Those who possess obscured and neutral form
definitely possess unobscured and neutral form.ğŸ”½There are those who possess unobscured and neutral form
but not obscured and neutral form.
This refers to those born in the desire realm.
If born in the form realm,
currently lacking obscured and neutral bodily and verbal expression.
The general and brief meaning explained above is as follows:
It means that those born in the desire or form realms definitely possess the four great elements.
Those born in the formless realm definitely do not possess them.
Unobscured and neutral form is also like this.
Good form, if born in the form realm, is definitely possessed.
If born in the desire or formless realms,
it may or may not be possessed.
Bad form, if born in the form or formless realms, is definitely not possessed.
If born in the desire realm, it may or may not be possessed.
Obscured and neutral form,
if born in the desire or formless realms, is definitely not possessed.
